SILAC labeling was performed as described elsewhere (15). glycine was added to a final concentration of 125 mm for 5 min at 37 °C. cells were harvested, washed three times with ice-cold washing buffer. cellular debris was removed via centrifugation for 30 min at 13,200 g at 4 °C. immunoprecipitation, 2 mg of protein from light siNC transfected cells was mixed with 2 mg of protein from heavy siBAG3 transfected HeLa cells. proteins were precleared with 0.2 ml protein A/G Sepharose for 2 h. gel sections were chopped into small particles, washed in water, and completely destained using 100 mm ammonium bicarbonate in 50% acetonitrile. Digestion was carried out using 20 g/ml sequencing-grade modified trypsin (Promega) in 50 mm ammonium bicarbonate. sufficient trypsin solution was added to swell gel pieces, which were kept at 4 °C for 45 min. supernatants were transferred into a 200-l microcentrifuge tube. ion selection thresholds were 1,000 counts for MS2 and 500 counts for MS3. an activation q = 0.25 and an activation time of 30 ms were applied. ion selection thresholds were 1,000 counts for MS2 and 500 counts for MS3. peptides were accepted if their Xcorr was greater than or equal to 1.9, 2.5, 3.5, or 4.5 for +1, +2, +3, and +4 charged ions. the global false discovery rate for both peptides and proteins was set to 0.01. the cells were lysed via shaking with glass beads. the supernatant was incubated with glutathione-Sepharose. the proteins were aliquoted into 384-well plates and printed onto Fullmoon slides. each protein was spotted in duplicate. genePix Pro 6.0 was used for data analysis. signal-to-noise ratios (SNR = F635 median/B635 median) were calculated. functional diversity among proteins present in two datasets was analyzed. the relative distribution of all proteins from Homo sapiens is shown by the line labeled “Expected” in Fig. 3. GO term enrichments were statistically evaluated with a modified Fisher's exact test (EASE score), and a p value for each term was calculated by applying a Benjamini-Hochberg false discovery rate correction (34, 35). 0.05. a human proteome microarray was used to identify putative BAG3 interacting proteins. 289 proteins identified as potential BAG3 interacting proteins. a statistical model was developed for estimating false positive rates. the discordant rate of two replicated microarrays could be controlled under 10%. known BAG3 interacting proteins, such as Hsp70 (5), sequestosome 1 (9), CCT (44), and HspB6 (45), were recovered in our datasets. each dataset contained a distinct group of proteins, and functional classification of these proteins allowed characterization of the different properties of the two datasets. in the proteome microarray dataset, adaptor and cytoskeletal proteins were the most overrepresented categories. the QUICK and proteome microarray methods combined the proteins identified by each method. a nonredundant list of 382 human proteins was used in all subsequent analyses. the interactome can be classified into 17 groups according to biological processes. d nodes are those that are significantly overrepresented in the GO biological processes. four major functional groups were strongly enriched in the BAG3 interactome. in the GO molecular function category, we found that the most overrepresented functions were involved in regulating enzyme activity. BAG3 forms a complex with Hsp90AA1, HspA1A, HSF1 and ST13 (Cluster 4) it is tempting to speculate that the physiological interaction between these two complexes might contribute to the cooperation and/or coordination of their functions in the control of numerous intracellular signaling and regulatory pathways. QUICK Identification of BAG3 Interacting Proteins We identified BAG3 interacting proteins first using the QUICK approach, a SILAC-based quantitative strategy to capture endogenous protein–protein interactions. levels of BAG3 proteins were markedly reduced in siBAG3-treated HeLa cells realative to HeLa cells transfected with negative control siRNA (siNC) level of BAG3 was 4.89-fold lower in the knock-down treatment than in the control (supplemental Table S1). a protein microarray composed of 17,000 individually purified human proteins was incubated with affinity-purified human BAG3 protein. to detect binding events, we applied a BAG3-specific monoclonal antibody to the microarray and followed with incubation with a Cy5-labeled secondary antibody. a control binding experiment was carried out in the absence of BAG3 on the human proteome microarray. many stronger signals can be observed from the microarray with and without BAG3 than from the microarray without BAG3. a substantial fraction of the proteins were shared between the two datasets. some of the known BAG3 interacting proteins, such as Hsp70 (5), sequestosome 1 (9), CCT (44), and HspB6 (45) were recovered in our datasets. array dataset were much less underrepresented than in QUICK (Fig. 3B) transcription factors and receptors are generally expressed at low levels (46), making them hard to identify with QUICK because the affinity purification step will most likely result in a loss of these proteins. a functional class performed a GO analysis to gain insights into the functional roles of the BAG3 interactome. we identified enriched terms in the GO biological process, molecular function, and cellular component analysis. ome proteins identified were localized in non-membrane-bounded organelles (p = 8.83 104), the cytosol (p = 6.23 1015), and the cytoskeleton (p = 2.99 104). regulating proteasome activity in cancer cells. consolidated these two datasets into a single set that was designated as the BAG3 interactome. this dataset should provide a starting point for more in-depth studies on the functions of BAG3. we report for the first time that BAG3 interacts with the proteasome and regulates its activity. AA1, Hsp90AB1, HspA1L, HspA1L, HspA2, and HspA8 among the BAG3 interacting proteins. different classes of heat shock proteins play diverse roles in governing proper protein assembly, folding, and translocation. seventeen of the BAG3 interacting proteins belong to the transfer/carrier protein class, including five ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes and two autophagy-related proteins (Atg3 and Atg7). the interaction of Atg3 with BAG3 was confirmed via reciprocal co-immunoprecipitation and SPR analysis. QUICK and proteome microarrays combine to obtain a comprehensive profile of protein–protein interactions. QUICK and proteome microarrays are complementary approaches.
